texts.definition: Having a perceived richness in possible choices without feeling tension from having too many of them, or having to prioritize between them.
markups: <style="Definition">Having a perceived richness in possible choices without feeling tension from having too many of them, or having to prioritize between them.</style>

Games often try to present players with a freedom regarding the actions possible in order for them to feel that they have meaningful choices. At the same time the games want to direct the activities gamers are having by interacting with them. <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> emerges when game design balanced these two aspects so players have a clear sense of what they can do but still feel unrestricted.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> and "tycoon" games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Tycoon%20series">Zoo Tycoon series</link></style> gives <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> to players by providing a simulation of a certain environment (a household in a city and a zoo respectively) and letting players choose their own goals within that context. This also goes for simulation games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/SimAnt">SimAnt</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/SimCity%20series">SimCity series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/SimEarth:%20The%20Living%20Planet">SimEarth: The Living Planet</link></style>. Although some grand strategy games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>, do have clear winning conditions and some do not, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style>, both types also have <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> in that there are relatively few choices in each moment of gameplay and players need to set their own long-term goals.

The possibility of building one's own complexes in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> is a form of <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> since they are restricted by the resources and tools players have gotten accesses to. The same applies to social network games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Subjective%20Patterns">Subjective Pattern</link></style> and as such can be difficult to design for broad groups of gamers. A general requirement is that players should have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> but without feelings that the games are enforcing goals or actions on them. For this reason, use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Goals">Enforced Goals</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> is difficult to combine with the <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> is often a core component of creative <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style>. One common pattern used in combination with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> is <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or patterns closely related to it, e.g. <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Landscaping">Landscaping</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agent%20Needs">Agent Needs</link></style> is another solution, e.g. present in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style>, since the needs expressed through this pattern provide explicit goals but does not enforce them. However, for <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> to exist the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> cannot allow too many different types of actions, and typically this also requires that the actions are explicitly presented to the players in some way. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> are natural way of supporting this and leads <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> to often have <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>.

The freedom aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> is often provided by offering <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sandbox%20Gameplay">Sandbox Gameplay</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player Defined Goals</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cheat%20Codes">Cheat Codes</link></style> is a way of letting players choose to have more freedom if they do not feel there is enough in a game, or lets players have <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> when they wish in games that otherwise do not support the pattern clearly. Other patterns that do not in themselves create <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> but can let players modulate the challenges of gameplay include <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> saves players from being overwhelmed with choices while at the same time giving them <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>. By doing so it enables players to set up reasonable goals without associating too much <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> with it. This makes games having the pattern an likely source for supporting <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style> activities and having experiences of <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Framed Freedom</style> often consists of handling <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, the pattern is often accompanied by <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>.
